Description: Terracotta figure of a naked youth squatting on the ground, leaning to the left. Nude temple boy. Traces of red paint over white coating. Mould-made and hollow. Fine light red-brown clay with buff surface. Base, hands and legs missing. Eroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Rhodian produced parallel from same mould series and in same fabric, dated 450 BC from the Fikellura Cemetery, Rhodes (GR 1864,1007.1910; Higgins 1970, 258-9). This style and subject is typical of mid 5th century BC in many Greek areas (Higgins 1970, 568; 835-7; 1159). Whilst in Rhodes and Cyprus, these represent temple boys, in Egypt they were reinterpreted as representations of Harpocrates.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.338) (Phase 3)
